body:
A couple of other points:

The pandas function has a parameter `string_as_factors`, which will convert columns of strings into R factors. That defaults to False (and this code uses the default for now), but when you load an R data.frame using `read.csv()`, string columns are treated as factors by default. Maybe the latter behaviour is more expected?

Dataframes converted like this show up slightly differently from dataframes loaded in R. A numeric column from the `str()` (structure) of each:
Loaded in R:
`$ samples: int  1 13 4 28 48 68 1 21 6 12 ...`
Converted:
`$ samples:Class 'AsIs'  num [1:69] 1 13 4 28 48 68 1 21 6 12 ...`

In my admittedly very brief tests, this doesn't seem to affect using the data, so I haven't followed it up. It may well be that it's an issue for pandas.

**Test results for commit 7c691b8 merged into master (55bf065)**
Platform: linux2
- python2.7: Failed, log at https://gist.github.com/4731215 (libraries not available: azure oct2py pymongo)
- python3.2: Failed, log at https://gist.github.com/4731216 (libraries not available: azure oct2py pymongo wx wx.aui)

Not available for testing: python2.6
Those failures are unrelated, due to issue #2890.

**Test results for commit 7c691b8 (can't merge cleanly)**
Platform: linux2
- python2.7: Failed, log at https://gist.github.com/4732581 (libraries not available: azure oct2py pymongo)
- python3.2: Failed, log at https://gist.github.com/4732582 (libraries not available: azure oct2py pymongo wx wx.aui)

Not available for testing: python2.6
I think that's an oddity of the Github API, it doesn't always show PRs as mergeable. Anyway, the tests for this bit do pass.
(The latest commit uses `strings_as_factors=True`)

Use rpy2's conversion system. Some aspects of it are a bit clunky but it is working (the `rpy2.robjects` layer is using it). 

Given the popularity of the pandas package, I think that it is making sense that I am including a conversion for its `DataFrame` in rpy2 (alongside with the conversion of numpy arrays already in).

In the meantime, iPython could already use that custom converter:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14656852/how-to-use-pandas-dataframes-and-numpy-arrays-in-rpy2/14789513#14789513

Great, I agree that it makes sense to have the conversion in rpy2. Is that in current releases, or is it something you're working on for a future release?

Does the custom converter you've linked to have any advantage over the code we're currently using in pandas? It looks more or less equivalent.

> Great, I agree that it makes sense to have the conversion in rpy2. Is that in current releases, or is it something you're working on for a future release?

Currently it is not in the code base (I'd need to add few bells and whistles, and the reverse conversion). Since the dev version of rpy2 is currently only targeting Python 3 and I am unsure about how well pandas is playing with Python 3 (last time I checked, around Christmas, numpy could not be installed on Python 3.3 here), a practical solution to get that to most users quickly is a bugfix release to the 2.3.x series of rpy2. This will be similar to the numpy conversion module in rpy2 (`pandas` not required for rpy2 to function, and the optional conversion can started with an import and a call to a function to activate it - that function can in turn be used by pandas, ipython, or other code to activate the conversion by default).

> Does the custom converter you've linked to have any advantage over the code we're currently using in pandas? It looks more or less equivalent.

Given that the few reports about pandas DataFrame objects not working with rpy2, I'd think that one advantage is that this code is working(and will be covered by unit tests once in the rpy2 code base). An other advantage is that the conversion is automatic at the `rpy2.robjects` layer (see examples in the SO answer).

Now in the branch `version_2.3.x` of the rpy2 repository (commit https://bitbucket.org/lgautier/rpy2/commits/0ff90649b2eb53b671f7e122c635dda9 and https://bitbucket.org/lgautier/rpy2/commits/113141e65aee5ef0c337028026ca7e728fd06ac2).

Usage is similar to the numpy conversion:

```
from rpy2.robjects import pandas2ri
pandas2ri.activate()
```

From IPython's point of view, we'd like to have it so that it acts on pandas DataFrames automatically, but it doesn't import pandas if it's not already loaded. So I guess we'd want something like

```
if 'pandas' in sys.modules:
    pandas2ri.activate()
```

Is it safe and quick to call that on each call to rmagic, or should we also check whether it's already activated?

Then again, pandas is quickly becoming pretty essential for data analysis in Python, so maybe it's not such a big problem to try to load it when rmagic is loaded.

The condition might always be true since`pandas.core.frame` will be implicitly imported by `pandas2ri`.

Otherwise, if going down the route of checking with each rmagic call, you could even set up the conversion each time (and restore  it when done). If rmagic is only used in interactive mode (that is no loops or high frequency calls), the performance penalty should be negligible.
It is actually possible to use in a loop - line magics are valid inside loops and function definitions. Although I doubt you get brilliant performance by mixing code in two languages, in any case.

Hmmm...just curious: would it be useful to have cell magics apply to a block rather than a whole cell?  Something like:

```
%%r:
    R code, indented
```

Anyway, food for thought...
Possibly, but it seems like quite a bit of extra complexity for relatively little gain.
But marking the end of a code cell is **needed** for ipy files so we should add a way to declare the end of a cell magic
Well, it currently follows the same rule that we have for our console interfaces - a blank line indicates that it's complete. This means that you can conveniently save history to a valid `.ipy` file.

No, currently cell magic don't work on master with ipy files (they sort of use to)

``` python
# content of foo.ipy
from time import sleep

%%capture
print('--foo--')

%%timeit sleep(0.1)
sleep(0.2)


sleep(0.4)
```

gives

```
$ ipython foo.ipy                                                                                                                                                                         [17:45:12]
ERROR: Line magic function `%capture` not found (But cell magic `%%capture` exists, did you mean that instead?).
--foo--
10 loops, best of 3: 100 ms per loop
```

Oh, well that's something else for me to do under IPEP2, then. Do you want
to file a bug so I don't forget it? It should be in the next PR after #2447
lands.

On 11 February 2013 16:48, Bussonnier Matthias notifications@github.comwrote:

> No, currently cell magic don't work on master with ipy files (they sort of
> use to)
> 
> # content of foo.ipyfrom time import sleep
> 
> %%captureprint('--foo--')
> %%timeit sleep(0.1)sleep(0.2)
> 
> sleep(0.4)
> 
> gives
> 
> $ ipython foo.ipy                                                                                                                                                                         [17:45:12]
> ERROR: Line magic function `%capture` not found (But cell magic `%%capture` exists, did you mean that instead?).
> --foo--
> 10 loops, best of 3: 100 ms per loop
> 
>  â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/2889#issuecomment-13389385.
Already opend as #2539 did assigned you.

This is functionality that I'd really like to see. Would it be acceptable to add a configuration option to enable it? That would deal with @takluyver's concerns about dependencies / extra cruft during rmagic loading. Swapping out the numpy2ri code for the following doesn't work:

```
from rpy2.robjects import pandas2ri
pandas2ri.activate()
```

This is due to `pyconverter` getting set to `np.asarray` in the `__init__`. So, I think this is a trivial change to do with a config option (`np.asarray` can be replaced with a null-op for pandas objects). But don't want to work on a clean solution if it's going to be rejected. In that case, I'll just make a quick hack for myself for now.

Hi @davclark . I need to get back to this, and integrate it with rpy2's pandas2ri/numpy2ri stuff properly, so that it doesn't conflict.

Making it a configuration option feels like a poor workaround, to be honest. If it's off by default, hardly anyone gets the benefit. If it's on by default, most users pay the performance cost anyway. My current thinking is that we may as well just let rmagic try to import pandas. It's only a one-off cost per kernel, and I think a lot of people using rmagic will be using pandas anyway, because DataFrame is so similar to R's data.frame.
May be you can make a toggle ? (e.g., %pdb toggles the PDB debugger upon errors)
OK then, I guess it's a quick hack for me for now (which I've done). If you want any help, just give a hollar.

I don't think a toggle would help much either - the import would only be done when you first load rmagic, so toggling it after that doesn't affect anything. As I say, I'm happy enough to just load pandas.

Probably worth keeping track of developments between rpy2 and pandas. See a related conversation here:  pydata/pandas#1448. Ultimately, ipython should probably not make itself a third place for implementing conversion code. So it probably makes sense to wait a _little_ longer to get the round-tripping implemented in the pandas2ri module in rpy2.
Yep - I haven't written any conversion code, this currently just calls pandas' conversion function. The conversion machinery in rpy2 will be preferred once I've got round to plugging that in.

OK, I've just updated this so that it prefers rpy2's pandas2ri module if that exists. I've also made `pyconverter` into a generic function using simplegeneric, so it's easier to extend.

We still need to work out something for the other direction - converting R to pandas. It looks like [pandas has some code for that](https://github.com/pydata/pandas/blob/master/pandas/rpy/common.py#L177) already. But that's less pressing for me, because I'm preparing data in Python and pushing it into R.
I think this is complete, so I'll merge it in a couple of days if there are no objections.
I added a comment about the np.asarray conversion in e2ca7dc. I started in your personal fork, but have re-commented in the (linked) ipython repo.
